Text: But they that were killing in the city of Susan, were employed in the slaughter on the thirteenth and fourteenth day of the same month: and on the fifteenth day they rested. And therefore they appointed that day to be a holy day of feasting and gladness.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But those Jews that dwelt in towns not walled and in villages, appointed the fourteenth day of the month Adar for banquets and gladness, so as to rejoice on that day, and send one another portions of their banquets and meats.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Mardochai wrote all these things, and sent them comprised in letters to the Jews that abode in all the king’s provinces, both those that lay near and those afar off,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That they should receive the fourteenth and fifteenth day of the month Adar for holy days, and always at the return of the year should celebrate them with solemn honour:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Because on those days the Jews revenged themselves of their enemies, and their mourning and sorrow were turned into mirth and joy, and that these should be days of feasting and gladness, in which they should send one to another portions of meats, and should give gifts to the poor.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the Jews undertook to observe with solemnity all they had begun to do at that time, which Mardochai by letters had commanded to be done.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For Aman, the son of Amadathi of the race of Agag, the enemy and adversary of the Jews, had devised evil against them, to kill them and destroy them; and had cast Phur, that is, the lot.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And afterwards Esther went in to the king, beseeching him that his endeavours might be made void by the king’s letters: and the evil that he had intended against the Jews, might return upon his own head. And so both he and his sons were hanged upon gibbets.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And since that time these days are called Phurim, that is, of lots: because Phur, that is, the lot, was cast into the urn. And all things that were done, are contained in the volume of this epistle, that is, of this book:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the things that they suffered, and that were afterwards changed, the Jews took upon themselves and their seed, and upon all that had a mind to be joined to their religion, so that it should be lawful for none to pass these days without solemnity: which the writing testifieth, and certain times require, as the years continually succeed one another.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: These are the days which shall never be forgot: and which all provinces in the whole world shall celebrate throughout all generations: neither is there any city wherein the days of Phurim, that is, of lots, must not be observed by the Jews, and by their posterity, which is bound to these ceremonies.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Esther the queen, the daughter of Abihail, and Mardochai the Jew, wrote also a second epistle, that with all diligence this day should be established a festival for the time to come.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And they sent to all the Jews that were in the hundred and twenty-seven provinces of king Assuerus, that they should have peace, and receive truth,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And observe the days of lots, and celebrate them with joy in their proper time: as Mardochai and Esther had appointed, and they undertook them to be observed by themselves and by their seed, fasts, and cries, and the days of lots,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And all things which are contained in the history of this book, which is called Esther. Esther Chapter 10 Assuerus’s greatness. Mardochai’s dignity.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And king Assuerus made all the land, and all the islands of the sea tributary.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And his strength and his empire, and the dignity and greatness wherewith he exalted Mardochai, are written in the books of the Medes, and of the Persians:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And how Mardochai of the race of the Jews, was next after king Assuerus: and great among the Jews, and acceptable to the people of his brethren, seeking the good of his people, and speaking those things which were for the welfare of his seed.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then Mardochai said: God hath done these things. Then Mardochai, etc.... Here St. Jerome advertiseth the reader, that what follows is not in the Hebrew, but is found in the septuagint Greek edition, which the seventy-two interpreters translated out of the Hebrew, or added by the inspiration of the Holy Ghost.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: I remember a dream that I saw, which signified these same things: and nothing thereof hath failed. A dream.... This dream was prophetical and extraordinary: otherwise the general rule is not to observe dreams.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The little fountain which grew into a river, and was turned into a light, and into the sun, and abounded into many waters, is Esther, whom the king married, and made queen.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But the two dragons are I and Aman.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The nations that were assembled are they that endeavoured to destroy the name of the Jews.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And my nation is Israel, who cried to the Lord, and the Lord saved his people: and he delivered us from all evils, and hath wrought great signs and wonders among the nations:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he commanded that there should be two lots, one of the people of God, and the other of all the nations.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And both lots came to the day appointed already from that time before God to all nations:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the Lord remembered his people, and had mercy on his inheritance.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And these days shall be observed in the month of Adar on the fourteenth, and fifteenth day of the same month, with all diligence, and joy of the people gathered into one assembly, throughout all the generations hereafter of the people of Israel. Esther Chapter 11 The dream of Mardochai, which in the ancient Greek and Latin Bibles was into the beginning of the book, but was detached by St. Jerome, and put in this place.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: In the fourth year of the reign of Ptolemy and Cleopatra, Dositheus, who said he was a priest, and of the Levitical race, and Ptolemy his son brought this epistle of Phurim, which they said Lysimachus the son of Ptolemy had interpreted in Jerusalem.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: In the second year of the reign of Artaxerxes the great, in the first day of the month Nisan, Mardochai the son of Jair, the son of Semei, the son of Cis, of the tribe of Benjamin:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: A Jew who dwelt in the city of Susan, a great man and among the first of the king’s court, had a dream.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now he was of the number of the captives, whom Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon had carried away from Jerusalem with Jechonias king of Juda:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And this was his dream: Behold there were voices, and tumults, and thunders, and earthquakes, and a disturbance upon the earth.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And behold two great dragons came forth ready to fight one against another.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And at their cry all nations were stirred up to fight against the nation of the just.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And that was a day of darkness and danger, of tribulation and distress, and great fear upon the earth.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the nation of the just was troubled fearing their own evils, and was prepared for death.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And they cried to God: and as they were crying, a little fountain grew into a very great river, and abounded into many waters.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The light and the sun rose up, and the humble were exalted, and they devoured the glorious.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when Mardochai had seen this, and arose out of his bed, he was thinking what God would do: and he kept it fixed in his mind, desirous to know what the dream should signify. Esther Chapter 12 Mardochai detects the conspiracy of the two eunuchs.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he abode at that time in the king’s court with Bagatha and Thara the king’s eunuchs, who were porters of the palace.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when he understood their designs, and had diligently searched into their projects, he learned that they went about to lay violent hands on king Artaxerxes, and he told the king thereof.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then the king had them both examined, and after they had confessed, commanded them to be put to death.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But the king made a record of what was done: and Mardochai also committed the memory of the thing to writing.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king commanded him, to abide in the court of the palace, and gave him presents for the information.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But Aman the son of Amadathi the Bugite was in great honour with the king, and sought to hurt Mardochai and his people, because of the two eunuchs of the king who were put to death. Esther Chapter 13 A copy of a letter sent by Aman to destroy the Jews. Mardochai’s prayer for the people.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And this was the copy of the letter: Artaxerxes the great king who reigneth from India to Ethiopia, to the princes and governors of the hundred and twenty-seven provinces, that are subject to his empire, greeting.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Whereas I reigned over many nations, and had brought all the world under my dominion, I was not willing to abuse the greatness of my power, but to govern my subjects with clemency and that they might live quietly without any terror, and might enjoy peace, which is desired by all men,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But when I asked my counsellors how this might be accomplished, one that excelled the rest in wisdom and fidelity, and was second after the king, Aman by name,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Told me that there was a people scattered through the whole world, which used new laws, and acted against the customs of all nations, despised the commandments of kings, and violated by their opposition the concord of all nations.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Wherefore having learned this, and seeing one nation in opposition to all mankind using perverse laws, and going against our commandments, and disturbing the peace and concord of the provinces subject to us,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: We have commanded that all whom Aman shall mark out, who is chief over all the provinces, and second after the king, and whom we honour as a father, shall be utterly destroyed by their enemies, with their wives and children, and that none shall have pity on them, on the fourteenth day of the twelfth month Adar of this present year:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That these wicked men going down to hell in one day, may restore to our empire the peace which they had disturbed.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But Mardochai besought the Lord, remembering all his works,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And said: O Lord, Lord, almighty king, for all things are in thy power, and there is none that can resist thy will, if thou determine to save Israel.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thou hast made heaven and earth and all things that are under the cope of heaven.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thou art Lord of all, and there is none that can resist thy majesty.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thou knowest all things, and thou knowest that it was not out of pride and or any desire of glory, that I refused to worship the proud Aman,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: (For I would willingly and readily for the salvation of Israel have kissed even the steps of his feet,)

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But I feared lest I should transfer the honour of my God to a man, and lest I should adore any one except my God.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And now, O Lord, O king, O God of Abraham, have mercy on thy people, because our enemies resolve to destroy us, and extinguish thy inheritance.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Despise not thy portion, which thou hast redeemed for thyself out of Egypt.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Hear my supplication, and be merciful to thy lot and inheritance, and turn our mourning into joy, that we may live and praise thy name, O Lord, and shut not the mouths of them that sing to thee.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And all Israel with like mind and supplication cried to the Lord, because they saw certain death hanging over their heads. Esther Chapter 14 The prayer of Esther for herself and her people.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Queen Esther also, fearing the danger that was at hand, had recourse to the Lord.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when she had laid away her royal apparel, she put on garments suitable for weeping and mourning: instead of divers precious ointments, she covered her head with ashes and dung, and she humbled her body with fasts: and all the places in which before she was accustomed to rejoice, she filled with her torn hair.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And she prayed to the Lord the God of Israel, saying: O my Lord, who alone art our king, help me a desolate woman, and who have no other helper but thee.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: My danger is in my hands.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: I have heard of my father that thou, O Lord, didst take Israel from among all nations, and our fathers from all their predecessors, to possess them as an everlasting inheritance, and thou hast done to them as thou hast promised.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: We have sinned in thy sight, and therefore thou hast delivered us into the hands of our enemies:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For we have worshipped their gods. Thou art just, O Lord.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And now they are not content to oppress us with most hard bondage, but attributing the strength of their hands to the power of their idols.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: They design to change thy promises, and destroy thy inheritance, and shut the mouths of them that praise thee, and extinguish the glory of thy temple and altar,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That they may open the mouths of Gentiles, and praise the strength of idols, and magnify for ever a carnal king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Give not, O Lord, thy sceptre to them that are not, lest they laugh at our ruin: but turn their counsel upon themselves, and destroy him that hath begun to rage against us.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Remember, O Lord, and shew thyself to us in the time of our tribulation, and give me boldness, O Lord, king of gods, and of all power:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Give me a well ordered speech in my mouth in the presence of the lion, and turn his heart to the hatred of our enemy, that both he himself may perish, and the rest that consent to him.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But deliver us by thy hand, and help me, who have no other helper, but thee, O Lord, who hast the knowledge of all things.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And thou knowest that I hate the glory of the wicked, and abhor the bed of the uncircumcised, and of every stranger.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thou knowest my necessity, that I abominate the sign of my pride and glory, which is upon my head in the days of my public appearance, and detest it as a menstruous rag, and wear it not in the days of my silence,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And that I have not eaten at Aman’s table, nor hath the king’s banquet pleased me, and that I have not drunk the wine of the drink offerings:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And that thy handmaid hath never rejoiced, since I was brought hither unto this day but in thee, O Lord, the God of Abraham.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: O God, who art mighty above all, hear the voice of them, that have no other hope, and deliver us from the hand of the wicked, and deliver me from my fear. Esther Chapter 15 Esther comes into the king’s presence: she is terrified, but God turns his heart.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he commanded her (no doubt but he was Mardochai) to go to the king, and petition for her people, and for her country.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Remember, (said he,) the days of thy low estate, how thou wast brought up by my hand, because Aman the second after the king hath spoken against us unto death.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And do thou call upon the Lord, and speak to the king for us, and deliver us from death.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And on the third day she laid away the garments she wore, and put on her glorious apparel.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And glittering in royal robes, after she had called upon God the ruler and Saviour of all, she took two maids with her,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And upon one of them she leaned, as if for delicateness and overmuch tenderness she were not able to bear up her own body.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the other maid followed her lady, bearing up her train flowing on the ground.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But she with a rosy colour in her face, and with gracious and bright eyes hid a mind full of anguish, and exceeding great fear.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So going in she passed through all doors in order, and stood before the king, where he sat upon his royal throne, clothed with his royal robes, and glittering with gold, and precious stones, and he was terrible to behold.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when he had lifted up his countenance, and with burning eyes had shewn the wrath of his heart, the queen sunk down, and her colour turned pale, and she rested her weary head upon her handmaid.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And God changed the king’s spirit into mildness, and all in haste and in fear he leaped from his throne, and holding her up in his arms, till she came to herself, caressed her with these words:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: What is the matter, Esther? I am thy brother, fear not.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thou shalt not die: for this law is not made for thee, but for all others.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Come near then, and touch the sceptre.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And as she held her peace, he took the golden sceptre, and laid it upon her neck, and kissed her, and said: Why dost thou not speak to me?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: She answered: I saw thee, my lord, as an angel of God, and my heart was troubled for fear of thy majesty.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For thou, my lord, art very admirable, and thy face is full of graces.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And while she was speaking, she fell down again, and was almost in a swoon.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But the king was troubled, and all his servants comforted her. Esther Chapter 16 A copy of the king’s letter in favour of the Jews.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The great king Artaxerxes, from India to Ethiopia, to the governors and princes of a hundred and twenty-seven provinces, which obey our command, sendeth greeting. From India to Ethiopia.... That is, who reigneth from India to Ethiopia.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Many have abused unto pride the goodness of princes, and the honour that hath been bestowed upon them:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And not only endeavour to oppress the king’s subjects, but not bearing the glory that is given them, take in hand, to practise also against them that gave it.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Neither are they content not to return thanks for benefits received, and to violate in themselves the laws of humanity, but they think they can also escape the justice of God who seeth all things.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And they break out into so great madness, as to endeavour to undermine by lies such as observe diligently the offices committed to them, and do all things in such manner as to be worthy of all men’s praise,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: While with crafty fraud they deceive the ears of princes that are well meaning, and judge of others by their own nature.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now this is proved both from ancient histories, and by the things which are done daily, how the good designs of kings are depraved by the evil suggestions of certain men.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Wherefore we must provide for the peace of all provinces.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Neither must you think, if we command different things, that it cometh of the levity of our mind, but that we give sentence according to the quality and necessity of times, as the profit of the commonwealth requireth.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now that you may more plainly understand what we say, Aman the son of Amadathi, a Macedonian both in mind and country, and having nothing of the Persian blood, but with his cruelty staining our goodness, was received being a stranger by us:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And found our humanity so great towards him, that he was called our father, and was worshipped by all as the next man after the king:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But he was so far puffed up with arrogancy, as to go about to deprive us of our kingdom and life.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For with certain new and unheard of devices he hath sought the destruction of Mardochai, by whose fidelity and good services our life was saved, and of Esther the partner of our kingdom with all their nation:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Thinking that after they were slain, he might work treason against us left alone without friends, and might transfer the kingdom of the Persians to the Macedonians.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But we have found that the Jews, who were by that most wicked man appointed to be slain, are in no fault at all, but contrariwise, use just laws,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And are the children of the highest and the greatest, and the ever living God, by whose benefit the kingdom was given both to our fathers and to us, and is kept unto this day.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Wherefore know ye that those letters which he sent in our name, are void and of no effect.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For which crime both he himself that devised it, and all his kindred hang on gibbets, before the gates of this city Susan: not we, but God repaying him as he deserved.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But this edict, which we now send, shall be published in all cities, that the Jews may freely follow their own laws.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And you shall aid them that they may kill those who had prepared themselves to kill them, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is called Adar.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For the almighty God hath turned this day of sadness and mourning into joy to them.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Wherefore you shall also count this day among other festival days, and celebrate it with all joy, that it may be known also in times to come,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That all they who faithfully obey the Persians, receive a worthy reward for their fidelity: but they that are traitors to their kingdom, are destroyed for their wickedness.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And let every province and city, that will not be partaker of this solemnity, perish by the sword and by fire, and be destroyed in such manner as to be made unpassable, both to men and beasts, for an example of contempt, and disobedience.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Paul, called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Sosthenes a brother,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To the church of God that is at Corinth, to them that are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be saints, with all that invoke the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place of theirs and ours.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Grace to you and peace, from God our father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I give thanks to my God always for you, for the grace of God that is given you in Christ Jesus:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That in all things you are made rich in him, in all utterance and in all knowledge;

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As the testimony of Christ was confirmed in you,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So that nothing is wanting to you in any grace, waiting for the manifestation of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who also will confirm you unto the end without crime, in the day of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: God is faithful: by whom you are called unto the fellowship of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I beseech you, brethren, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you all speak the same thing and that there be no schisms among you: but that you be perfect in the same mind and in the same judgment.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it hath been signified unto me, my brethren, of you, by them that are of the house of Chloe, that there are contentions among you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I say, that every one of you saith: I indeed am of Paul; and I am of Apollo; and I of Cephas; and I of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Is Christ divided? Was Paul then crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I give God thanks, that I baptized none of you but Crispus and Caius:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Lest any should say that you were baptized in my name.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I baptized also the household of Stephanus. Besides, I know not whether I baptized any other.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the gospel: not in wisdom of speech, lest the cross of Christ should be made void.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the word of the cross, to them indeed that perish, is foolishness: but to them that are saved, that is, to us, it is the power of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it is written: I will destroy the wisdom of the wise: and the prudence of the prudent I will reject.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the disputer of this world? Hath not God made foolish the wisdom of this world?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For, seeing that in the wisdom of God, the world, by wisdom, knew not God, it pleased God, by the foolishness of our preaching, to save them that believe.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For both the Jews require signs: and the Greeks seek after wisdom.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we preach Christ crucified: unto the Jews indeed a stumblingblock, and unto the Gentiles foolishness:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But unto them that are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ, the power of God and the wisdom of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the foolishness of God is wiser than men: and the weakness of God is stronger than men. The foolishness, etc.... That is to say, what appears foolish to the world in the ways of God, is indeed most wise; and what appears weak is indeed above all the strength and comprehension of man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For see your vocation, brethren, that there are not many wise according to the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the foolish things of the world hath God chosen, that he may confound the wise: and the weak things of the world hath God chosen, that he may confound the strong.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the base things of the world and the things that are contemptible, hath God chosen: and things that are not, that he might bring to nought things that are:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That no flesh should glory in his sight.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But of him are you in Christ Jesus, who of God is made unto us wisdom and justice and sanctification and redemption:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That, as it is written: He that glorieth may glory in the Lord. 1 Corinthians Chapter 2 His preaching was not in loftiness of words, but in spirit and power. And the wisdom he taught was not to be understood by the worldly wise or sensual man, but only by the spiritual man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I, brethren, when I came to you, came not in loftiness of speech or of wisdom, declaring unto you the testimony of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I judged not myself to know anything among you, but Jesus Christ: and him crucified.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I was with you in weakness and in fear and in much trembling.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And my speech and my preaching was not in the persuasive words of human wisdom, but in shewing of the Spirit and power:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That your faith might not stand on the wisdom of men, but on the power of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Howbeit we speak wisdom among the perfect: yet not the wisdom of this world, neither of the princes of this world that come to nought.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, a wisdom which is hidden, which God ordained before the world, unto our glory:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Which none of the princes of this world knew. For if they had known it, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But, as it is written: That eye hath not seen, nor ear heard: neither hath it entered into the heart of man, what things God hath prepared for them that love him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to us God hath revealed them by his Spirit. For the Spirit searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For what man knoweth the things of a man, but the spirit of a man that is in him? So the things also that are of God, no man knoweth, but the Spirit of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, we have received not the spirit of this world, but the Spirit that is of God: that we may know the things that are given us from God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Which things also we speak: not in the learned words of human wisdom, but in the doctrine of the Spirit, comparing spiritual things with spiritual.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the sensual man perceiveth not these things that are of the Spirit of God. For it is foolishness to him: and he cannot understand, because it is spiritually examined. The sensual man—the spiritual man.... The sensual man is either he who is taken up with sensual pleasures, with carnal and worldly affections; or he who measureth divine mysteries by natural reason, sense, and human wisdom only. Now such a man has little or no notion of the things of God. Whereas the spiritual man is he who, in the mysteries of religion, takes not human sense for his guide: but submits his judgment to the decisions of the church, which he is commanded to hear and obey. For Christ hath promised to remain to the end of the world with his church, and to direct her in all things by the Spirit of truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the spiritual man judgeth all things: and he himself is judged of no man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For who hath known the mind of the Lord, that he may instruct him? But we have the mind of Christ. 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 They must not contend about their teachers, who are but God’s ministers and accountable to him. Their works shall be tried by fire.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I, brethren, could not speak to you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal. As unto little ones in Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I gave you milk to drink, not meat: for you were not able as yet. But neither indeed are you now able: for you are yet carnal.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For, whereas there is among you envying and contention, are you not carnal and walk you not according to man?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For while one saith: I indeed am of Paul: and another: I am of Apollo: are you not men? What then is Apollo and what is Paul?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The ministers of him whom you have believed: and to every one as the Lord hath given.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I have planted, Apollo watered: but God gave the increase.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, neither he that planteth is any thing, nor he that watereth: but God that giveth the increase.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now he that planteth and he that watereth, are one. And every man shall receive his own reward, according to his own labour.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we are God’s coadjutors. You are God’s husbandry: you are God’s building.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: According to the grace of God that is given to me, as a wise architect, I have laid the foundation: and another buildeth thereon. But let every man take heed how he buildeth thereupon.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For other foundation no man can lay, but that which is laid: which is Christ Jesus.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, if any man build upon this foundation, gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, stubble: Upon this foundation.... The foundation is Christ and his doctrine: or the true faith in him, working through charity. The building upon this foundation gold, silver, and precious stones, signifies the more perfect preaching and practice of the gospel; the wood, hay, and stubble, such preaching as that of the Corinthian teachers (who affected the pomp of words and human eloquence) and such practice as is mixed with much imperfection, and many lesser sins. Now the day of the Lord, and his fiery trial, (in the particular judgment immediately after death,) shall make manifest of what sort every man’s work has been: of which, during this life, it is hard to make a judgment. For then the fire of God’s judgment shall try every man’s work. And they, whose works, like wood, hay, and stubble, cannot abide the fire, shall suffer loss; these works being found to be of no value; yet they themselves, having built upon the right foundation, (by living and dying in the true faith and in the state of grace, though with some imperfection,) shall be saved yet so as by fire; being liable to this punishment, by reason of the wood, hay, and stubble, which was mixed with their building.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Every man’s work shall be manifest. For the day of the Lord shall declare it, because it shall be revealed in fire. And the fire shall try every man’s work, of what sort it is.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man’s work abide, which he hath built thereupon, he shall receive a reward.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man’s work burn, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved, yet so as by fire.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man violate the temple of God, him shall God destroy. For the temple of God is holy, which you are.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man deceive himself. If any man among you seem to be wise in this world, let him become a fool, that he may be wise.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. For it is written: I will catch the wise in their own craftiness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And again: The Lord knoweth the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man therefore glory in men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For all things are yours, whether it be Paul or Apollo or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come. For all are yours.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And you are Christ’s. And Christ is God’s. 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 God’s ministers are not to be judged. He reprehends their boasting of their preachers and describes the treatment the apostles every where met with.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let a man so account of us as of the ministers of Christ and the dispensers of the mysteries of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Here now it is required among the dispensers that a man be found faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to me it is a very small thing to be judged by you or by man’s day. But neither do I judge my own self.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I am not conscious to myself of anything. Yet am I not hereby justified: but he that judgeth me is the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, judge not before the time: until the Lord come, who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkness and will make manifest the counsels of the hearts. And then shall every man have praise from God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But these things, brethren, I have in a figure transferred to myself and to Apollo, for your sakes: that in us you may learn that one be not puffed up against the other for another, above that which is written.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For who distinguisheth thee? Or what hast thou that thou hast not received, and if thou hast received, why dost thou glory, as if thou hadst not received it?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are now full: you are now become rich: you reign without us; and I would to God you did reign, that we also might reign with you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I think that God hath set forth us apostles, the last, as it were men appointed to death. We are made a spectacle to the world and to angels and to men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ: we are weak, but you are strong: you are honourable, but we without honour.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Even unto this hour we both hunger and thirst and are naked and are buffeted and have no fixed abode.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And we labour, working with our own hands. We are reviled: and we bless. We are persecuted: and we suffer it.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We are blasphemed: and we entreat. We are made as the refuse of this world, the offscouring of all, even until now.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I write not these things to confound you: but I admonish you as my dearest children.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if you have ten thousand instructors in Christ, yet not many fathers. For in Christ Jesus, by the gospel, I have begotten you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, I beseech you, be ye followers of me as I also am of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For this cause have I sent to you Timothy, who is my dearest son and faithful in the Lord. Who will put you in mind of my ways, which are in Christ Jesus: as I teach every where in every church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As if I would not come to you, so some are puffed up.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I will come to you shortly, if the Lord will: and will know, not the speech of them that are puffed up, but the power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the kingdom of God is not in speech, but in power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What will you? Shall I come to you with a rod? Or in charity and in the spirit of meekness? 1 Corinthians Chapter 5 He excommunicates the incestuous adulterer and admonishes them to purge out the old leaven.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: It is absolutely heard that there is fornication among you and such fornication as the like is not among the heathens: that one should have his father’s wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And you are puffed up and have not rather mourned: that he might be taken away from among you that hath done this thing.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I indeed, absent in body but present in spirit, have already judged, as though I were present, him that hath so done,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, you being gathered together and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To deliver such a one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Your glorying is not good. Know you not that a little leaven corrupteth the whole lump?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Purge out the old leaven, that you may be a new paste, as you are unleavened. For Christ our pasch is sacrificed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, let us feast, not with the old leaven, nor with the leaven of malice and wickedness: but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I wrote to you in an epistle not to keep company with fornicators.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I mean not with the fornicators of this world or with the covetous or the extortioners or the servers of idols: otherwise you must needs go out of this world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now I have written to you, not to keep company, if any man that is named a brother be a fornicator or covetous or a server of idols or a railer or a drunkard or an extortioner: with such a one, not so much as to eat.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For what have I to do to judge them that are without? Do not you judge them that are within?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For them that are without, God will judge. Put away the evil one from among yourselves. 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 He blames them for going to law before unbelievers. Of sins that exclude from the kingdom of heaven. The evil of fornication.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Dare any of you, having a matter against another, go to be judged before the unjust: and not before the saints?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that the saints shall judge this world? And if the world shall be judged by you, are you unworthy to judge the smallest matters?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that we shall judge angels? How much more things of this world?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If therefore you have judgments of things pertaining to this world, set them to judge who are the most despised in the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak to your shame. Is it so that there is not among you any one wise man that is able to judge between his brethren?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But brother goeth to law with brother: and that before unbelievers.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Already indeed there is plainly a fault among you, that you have law suits one with another. Why do you not rather take wrong? Why do you not rather suffer yourselves to be defrauded? A fault.... Lawsuits can hardly ever be without a fault, on the one side or the other; and oftentimes on both sides.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But you do wrong and defraud: and that to your brethren.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that the unjust shall not possess the kingdom of God? Do not err: Neither fornicators nor idolaters nor adulterers:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Nor the effeminate nor liers with mankind nor thieves nor covetous nor drunkards nor railers nor extortioners shall possess the kingdom of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And such some of you were. But you are washed: but you are sanctified: but you are justified: in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and the Spirit of our God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All things are lawful to me: but all things are not expedient. All things are lawful to me: but I will not be brought under the power of any. All things are lawful, etc.... That is, all indifferent things are indeed lawful, inasmuch as they are not prohibited; but oftentimes they are not expedient; as in the case of lawsuits, etc. And much less would it be expedient to be enslaved by an irregular affection to any thing, how indifferent soever.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Meat for the belly and the belly for the meats: but God shall destroy both it and them. But the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord: and the Lord for the body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now God hath both raised up the Lord, and will raise us up also by his power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that your bodies are the members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid!

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or know you not that he who is joined to a harlot is made one body? For they shall be, saith he, two in one flesh.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he who is joined to the Lord is one spirit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Fly fornication. Every sin that a man doth is without the body: but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or know you not that your members are the temple of the Holy Ghost, who is in you, whom you have from God: and you are not your own?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you are bought with a great price. Glorify and bear God in your body. 1 Corinthians Chapter 7 Lessons relating to marriage and celibacy. Virginity is preferable to a married state.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning the things whereof you wrote to me: It is good for a man not to touch a woman.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But for fear of fornication, let every man have his own wife: and let every woman have her own husband. Have his own wife.... That is, keep to his wife, which he hath. His meaning is not to exhort the unmarried to marry: on the contrary, he would have them rather continue as they are. (Ver. 7:8.) But he speaks here to them that are already married; who must not depart from one another, but live together as they ought to do in the marriage state.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let the husband render the debt to his wife: and the wife also in like manner to the husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The wife hath not power of her own body: but the husband. And in like manner the husband also hath not power of his own body: but the wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Defraud not one another, except, perhaps, by consent, for a time, that you may give yourselves to prayer: and return together again, lest Satan tempt you for your incontinency.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I speak this by indulgence, not by commandment. By indulgence.... That is, by a condescension to your weakness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I would that all men were even as myself. But every one hath his proper gift from God: one after this manner, and another after that.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I say to the unmarried and to the widows: It is good for them if they so continue, even as I.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if they do not contain themselves, let them marry. For it is better to marry than to be burnt. If they do not contain, etc.... This is spoken of such as are free, and not of such as, by vow, have given their first faith to God; to whom if they will use proper means to obtain it, God will never refuse the gift of continency. Some translators have corrupted this text, by rendering it, if they cannot contain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to them that are married, not I, but the Lord, commandeth that the wife depart not from her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if she depart, that she remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband. And let not the husband put away his wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For to the rest I speak, not the Lord. If any brother hath a wife that believeth not and she consent to dwell with him: let him not put her away. I speak, not the Lord.... Viz., by any express commandment, or ordinance.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if any woman hath a husband that believeth not and he consent to dwell with her: let her not put away her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the believing wife: and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the believing husband. Otherwise your children should be unclean: but now they are holy. Is sanctified.... The meaning is not, that the faith of the husband or the wife is of itself sufficient to put the unbelieving party, or their children, in the state of grace and salvation; but that it is very often an occasion of their sanctification, by bringing them to the true faith.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if the unbeliever depart, let him depart. For a brother or sister is not under servitude in such cases. But God hath called us in peace.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband? Or how knowest thou, O man, whether thou shalt save thy wife?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But as the Lord hath distributed to every one, as God hath called every one: so let him walk. And so in all churches I teach.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Is any man called, being circumcised? Let him not procure uncircumcision. Is any man called in uncircumcision? Let him not be circumcised.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Circumcision is nothing and uncircumcision is nothing: but the observance of the commandments of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let every man abide in the same calling in which he was called.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wast thou called, being a bondman? Care not for it: but if thou mayest be made free, use it rather.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that is called in the Lord, being a bondman, is the freeman of the Lord. Likewise he that is called, being free, is the bondman of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are bought with a price: be not made the bondslaves of men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Brethren, let every man, wherein he was called, therein abide with God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, concerning virgins, I have no commandment of the Lord: but I give counsel, as having obtained mercy of the Lord, to be faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I think therefore that this is good for the present necessity: that it is good for a man so to be.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Art thou bound to a wife? Seek not to be loosed. Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if thou take a wife, thou hast not sinned. And if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned: nevertheless, such shall have tribulation of the flesh. But I spare you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: This therefore I say, brethren: The time is short. It remaineth, that they also who have wives be as if they had none:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And they that weep, as though they wept not: and they that rejoice, as if they rejoiced not: and they that buy as if they possessed not:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And they that use this world, as if they used it not. For the fashion of this world passeth away.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I would have you to be without solicitude. He that is without a wife is solicitous for the things that belong to the Lord: how he may please God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he that is with a wife is solicitous for the things of the world: how he may please his wife. And he is divided.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the unmarried woman and the virgin thinketh on the things of the Lord: that she may be holy both in body and in spirit. But she that is married thinketh on the things of the world: how she may please her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And this I speak for your profit, not to cast a snare upon you, but for that which is decent and which may give you power to attend upon the Lord, without impediment.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man think that he seemeth dishonoured with regard to his virgin, for that she is above the age, and it must so be: let him do what he will. He sinneth not if she marry. Let him do what he will; he sinneth not, etc.... The meaning is not, as libertines would have it, that persons may do what they will and not sin, provided they afterwards marry; but that the father, with regard to the giving his virgin in marriage, may do as he pleaseth; and that it will be no sin to him if she marry.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that hath determined, being steadfast in his heart, having no necessity, but having power of his own will: and hath judged this in his heart, to keep his virgin, doth well.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore both he that giveth his virgin in marriage doth well: and he that giveth her not doth better.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: A woman is bound by the law as long as her husband liveth: but if her husband die, she is at liberty. Let her marry to whom she will: only in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But more blessed shall she be, if she so remain, according to my counsel. And I think that I also have the spirit of God. 1 Corinthians Chapter 8 Though an idol be nothing, yet things offered up to idols are not to be eaten, for fear of scandal.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning those things that are sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge puffeth up: but charity edifieth. Knowledge puffeth up, etc.... Knowledge, without charity and humility, serveth only to puff persons up.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if any man think that he knoweth any thing, he hath not yet known as he ought to know.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man love God, the same is known by him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But as for the meats that are sacrificed to idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world and that there is no God but one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For although there be that are called gods, either in heaven or on earth (for there be gods many and lords many): Gods many, etc.... Reputed for such among the heathens.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yet to us there is but one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we unto him: and one Lord Jesus Christ, by whom are all things, and we by him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But there is not knowledge in every one. For some until this present, with conscience of the idol, eat as a thing sacrificed to an idol: and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But meat doth not commend us to God. For neither, if we eat, shall we have the more: nor, if we eat not, shall we have the less.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But take heed lest perhaps this your liberty become a stumblingblock to the weak.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if a man see him that hath knowledge sit at meat in the idol’s temple, shall not his conscience, being weak, be emboldened to eat those things which are sacrificed to idols?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And through thy knowledge shall the weak brother perish, for whom Christ hath died?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now when you sin thus against the brethren and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, if meat scandalize my brother, I will never eat flesh, lest I should scandalize my brother. If meat scandalize.... That is, if my eating cause my brother to sin. 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 The apostle did not make use of his power of being maintained at the charges of those to whom he preached, that he might give no hindrance to the gospel. Of running in the race and striving for the mastery.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Am not I free? Am not I an apostle? Have not I seen Christ Jesus our Lord? Are not you my work in the Lord?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if unto others I be not an apostle, but yet to you I am. For you are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: My defence with them that do examine me is this.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Have not we power to eat and to drink?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Have we not power to carry about a woman, a sister as well as the rest of the apostles and the brethren of the Lord and Cephas? A woman, a sister.... Some erroneous translators have corrupted this text by rendering it, a sister, a wife: whereas, it is certain, St. Paul had no wife (chap. 7 ver. 7, 8) and that he only speaks of such devout women, as, according to the custom of the Jewish nation, waited upon the preachers of the gospel, and supplied them with necessaries.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or I only and Barnabas, have not we power to do this?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who serveth as a soldier, at any time, at his own charges? Who planteth a vineyard and eateth not of the fruit thereof? Who feedeth the flock and eateth not of the milk of the flock?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Speak I these things according to man? Or doth not the law also say; these things?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it is written in the law of Moses: Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn. Doth God take care for oxen?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or doth he say this indeed for our sakes? For these things are written for our sakes: that he that plougheth, should plough in hope and he that thrasheth, in hope to receive fruit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If we have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we reap your carnal things?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If others be partakers of this power over you, why not we rather? Nevertheless, we have not used this power: but we bear all things, lest we should give any hindrance to the gospel of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that they who work in the holy place eat the things that are of the holy place; and they that serve the altar partake with the altar?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So also the Lord ordained that they who preach the gospel should live by the gospel.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I have used none of these things. Neither have I written these things, that they should be so done unto me: for it is good for me to die rather than that any man should make my glory void.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if I preach the gospel, it is no glory to me: for a necessity lieth upon me. For woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel. It is no glory.... That is, I have nothing to glory of.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if I do this thing willingly, I have a reward: but if against my will, a dispensation is committed to me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What is my reward then? That preaching the gospel, I may deliver the gospel without charge, that I abuse not my power in the gospel.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For whereas I was free as to all, I made myself the servant of all, that I might gain the more.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I became to the Jews a Jew, that I might gain the Jews:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To them that are under the law, as if I were under the law, (whereas myself was not under the law,) that I might gain them that were under the law. To them that were without the law, as if I were without the law, (whereas I was not without the law of God, but was in the law of Christ,) that I might gain them that were without the law.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To the weak I became weak, that I might gain the weak. I became all things to all men, that I might save all.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I do all things for the gospel’s sake, that I may be made partaker thereof.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that they that run in the race, all run indeed, but one receiveth the prize. So run that you may obtain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And every one that striveth for the mastery refraineth himself from all things. And they indeed that they may receive a corruptible crown: but we an incorruptible one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I therefore so run, not as at an uncertainty: I so fight, not as one beating the air.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I chastise my body and bring it into subjection: lest perhaps, when I have preached to others, I myself should become a castaway. I chastise, etc.... Here St. Paul shews the necessity of self-denial and mortification, to subdue the flesh, and its inordinate desires. 1 Corinthians Chapter 10 By the example of the Israelites, he shews that we are not to build too much upon favours received but to avoid their sins and fly from the service of idols and from things offered to idols.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I would not have you ignorant, brethren, that our fathers were all under the cloud: and all passed through the sea.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And all in Moses were baptized, in the cloud and in the sea: In Moses.... Under the conduct of Moses, they received baptism in figure, by passing under the cloud, and through the sea; and they partook of the body and blood of Christ in figure, by eating of the manna, (called here a spiritual food because it was a figure of the true bread which comes down from heaven,) and drinking the water, miraculously brought out of the rock, called here a spiritual rock, because it was also a figure of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And did all eat the same spiritual food:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And all drank the same spiritual drink: (And they drank of the spiritual rock that followed them: and the rock was Christ.)

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But with most of them God was not well pleased: for they were overthrown in the desert.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now these things were done in a figure of us, that we should not covet evil things, as they also coveted.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither become ye idolaters, as some of them, as it is written: The people sat down to eat and drink and rose up to play.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither let us commit fornication, as some of them committed fornication: and there fell in one day three and twenty thousand.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither let us tempt Christ, as some of them tempted and perished by the serpents.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither do you murmur, as some of them murmured and were destroyed by the destroyer.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now all these things happened to them in figure: and they are written for our correction, upon whom the ends of the world are come. The ends of the world.... That is, the last ages.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, he that thinketh himself to stand, let him take heed lest he fall.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no temptation take hold on you, but such as is human. And God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that which you are able: but will make also with temptation issue, that you may be able to bear it. Or.... no temptation hath taken hold of you.... or come upon you as yet, but what is human, or incident to man. Issue.... or a way to escape.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, my dearly beloved, fly from the service of idols.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak as to wise men: judge ye yourselves what I say.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The chalice of benediction which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? And the bread which we break, is it not the partaking of the body of the Lord? Which we bless.... Here the apostle puts them in mind of their partaking of the body and blood of Christ in the sacred mysteries, and becoming thereby one mystical body with Christ. From whence he infers, ver. 21, that they who are made partakers with Christ, by the eucharistic sacrifice and sacrament, must not be made partakers with devils by eating of the meats sacrificed to them.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we, being many, are one bread, one body: all that partake of one bread. One bread.... or, as it may be rendered, agreeably both to the Latin and Greek, because the bread is one, all we, being many, are one body, who partake of that one bread. For it is by our communicating with Christ, and with one another, in this blessed sacrament, that we are formed into one mystical body; and made, as it were, one bread, compounded of many grains of corn, closely united together.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Behold Israel according to the flesh. Are not they that eat of the sacrifices partakers of the altar?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What then? Do I say that what is offered in sacrifice to idols is any thing? Or that the idol is any thing?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the things which the heathens sacrifice, they sacrifice to devils and not to God. And I would not that you should be made partakers with devils.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You cannot drink the chalice of the Lord and the chalice of devils: you cannot be partakers of the table of the Lord and of the table of devils.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he? All things are lawful for me: but all things are not expedient.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All things are lawful for me: but all things do not edify.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man seek his own, but that which is another’s.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, eat: asking no question for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The earth is the Lord’s and the fulness thereof.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any of them that believe not, invite you, and you be willing to go: eat of any thing that is set before you, asking no question for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man say: This has been sacrificed to idols: do not eat of it, for his sake that told it and for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Conscience I say, not thy own, but the other’s. For why is my liberty judged by another man’s conscience?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If I partake with thanksgiving, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, whether you eat or drink, or whatsoever else you do, do all to the glory of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Be without offence to the Jew, and to the Gentiles and to the church of God:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As I also in all things please all men, not seeking that which is profitable to myself but to many: that they may be saved. 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Women must have a covering over their heads. He blameth the abuses of their love feasts and upon that occasion treats of the Blessed Sacrament.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Be ye followers of me, as I also am of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I praise you, brethren, that in all things you are mindful of me and keep my ordinances as I have delivered them to you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I would have you know that the head of every man is Christ: and the head of the woman is the man: and the head of Christ is God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Every man praying or prophesying with his head covered disgraceth his head.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But every woman praying or prophesying with her head not covered disgraceth her head: for it is all one as if she were shaven.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if a woman be not covered, let her be shorn. But if it be a shame to a woman to be shorn or made bald, let her cover her head.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The man indeed ought not to cover his head: because he is the image and glory of God. But the woman is the glory of the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the man is not of the woman: but the woman of the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the man was not created for the woman: but the woman for the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore ought the woman to have a power over her head, because of the angels. A power.... that is, a veil or covering, as a sign that she is under the power of her husband: and this, the apostle adds, because of the angels, who are present in the assemblies of the faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But yet neither is the man without the woman, nor the woman without the man, in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For as the woman is of the man, so also is the man by the woman: but all things of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You yourselves judge. Doth it become a woman to pray unto God uncovered?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Doth not even nature itself teach you that a man indeed, if he nourish his hair, it is a shame unto him?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if a woman nourish her hair, it is a glory to her; for her hair is given to her for a covering.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man seem to be contentious, we have no such custom, nor the Church of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I ordain: not praising you, that you come together, not for the better, but for the worse.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For first of all I hear that when you come together in the church, there are schisms among you. And in part I believe it.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For there must be also heresies: that they also, who are approved may be made manifest among you. There must be also heresies.... By reason of the pride and perversity of man’s heart; not by God’s will or appointment; who nevertheless draws good out of this evil, manifesting, by that occasion, who are the good and firm Christians, and making their faith more remarkable.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: When you come therefore together into one place, it is not now to eat the Lord’s supper. The Lord’s supper.... So the apostle here calls the charity feasts observed by the primitive Christians; and reprehends the abuses of the Corinthians, on these occasions; which were the more criminal, because these feasts were accompanied with the celebrating of the eucharistic sacrifice and sacrament.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For every one taketh before his own supper to eat. And one indeed is hungry and another is drunk.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What, have you no houses to eat and to drink in? Or despise ye the church of God and put them to shame that have not? What shall I say to you? Do I praise you? In this I praise you not.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you, that the Lord Jesus, the same night in which he was betrayed, took bread,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And giving thanks, broke and said: Take ye and eat: This is my body, which shall be delivered for you. This do for the commemoration of me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In like manner also the chalice, after he had supped, saying: This chalice is the new testament in my blood. This do ye, as often as you shall drink, for the commemoration of me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For as often as you shall eat this bread and drink the chalice, you shall shew the death of the Lord, until he come.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, whosoever shall eat this bread, or drink the chalice of the Lord unworthily, shall be guilty of the body and of the blood of the Lord. Or drink.... Here erroneous translators corrupted the text, by putting and drink (contrary to the original) instead of or drink. Guilty of the body, etc., not discerning the body, etc.... This demonstrates the real presence of the body and blood of Christ, even to the unworthy communicant; who otherwise could not be guilty of the body and blood of Christ, or justly condemned for not discerning the Lord’s body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But let a man prove himself: and so let him eat of that bread and drink of the chalice. Drink of the chalice.... This is not said by way of command, but by way of allowance, viz., where and when it is agreeable to the practice and discipline of the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily eateth and drinketh judgment to himself, not discerning the body of the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
