Text: For God making promise to Abraham, because he had no one greater by whom he might swear, swore by himself,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Saying: Unless blessing I shall bless thee and multiplying I shall multiply thee.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And so patiently enduring he obtained the promise.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For men swear by one greater than themselves: and an oath for confirmation is the end of all their controversy.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherein God, meaning more abundantly to shew to the heirs of the promise the immutability of his counsel, interposed an oath:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: That by two immutable things in which it is impossible for God to lie, we may have the strongest comfort, we who have fled for refuge to hold fast the hope set before us.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Which we have as an anchor of the soul, sure and firm, and which entereth in even within the veil:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Where the forerunner Jesus is entered for us, made a high priest for ever according to the order of Melchisedech. Hebrews Chapter 7 The priesthood of Christ according to the order of Melchisedech excels the Levitical priesthood and puts an end both to that and to the law.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For this Melchisedech was king of Salem, priest of the most high God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: To whom also Abraham divided the tithes of all: who first indeed by interpretation is king of justice: and then also king of Salem, that is, king of peace:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but likened unto the Son of God, continueth a priest for ever. Without father, etc.... Not that he had no father, etc., but that neither his father, nor his pedigree, nor his birth, nor his death, are set down in scripture.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now consider how great this man is, to whom also Abraham the patriarch gave tithes out of the principal things.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And indeed they that are of the sons of Levi, who receive the priesthood, have a commandment to take tithes of the people according to the law, that is to say, of their brethren: though they themselves also came out of the loins of Abraham.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But he, whose pedigree is not numbered among them, received tithes of Abraham and blessed him that had the promises.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And without all contradiction, that which is less is blessed by the better.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And here indeed, men that die receive tithes: but there, he hath witness that he liveth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And (as it may be said) even Levi who received tithes paid tithes in Abraham:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For he was yet in the loins of his father when Melchisedech met him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: If then perfection was by the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people received the law), what further need was there that another priest should rise according to the order of Melchisedech: and not be called according to the order of Aaron?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For the priesthood being translated, it is necessary that a translation also be made of the law,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For he of whom these things are spoken is of another tribe, of which no one attended on the altar.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For it is evident that our Lord sprung out of Juda: in which tribe Moses spoke nothing concerning priests.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And it is yet far more evident: if according to the similitude of Melchisedech there ariseth another priest,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who is made, not according to the law of a carnal commandment, but according to the power of an indissoluble life.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For he testifieth: Thou art a priest for ever according to the order of Melchisedech.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: There is indeed a setting aside of the former commandment, because of the weakness and unprofitableness thereof:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For the law brought nothing to perfection: but a bringing in of a better hope, by which we draw nigh to God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And inasmuch as it is not without an oath (for the others indeed were made priests without an oath:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But this with an oath, by him that said unto him: The Lord hath sworn and he will not repent: Thou art a priest for ever).

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By so much is Jesus made a surety of a better testament.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And the others indeed were made many priests, because by reason of death they were not suffered to continue: Many priests, etc.... The apostle notes this difference between the high priests of the law, and our high priest Jesus Christ; that they being removed by death, made way for their successors; whereas our Lord Jesus is a priest for ever, and hath no successor; but liveth and concurreth for ever with his ministers, the priests of the new testament, in all their functions. Also, that no one priest of the law, nor all of them together, could offer that absolute sacrifice of everlasting redemption, which our one high priest Jesus Christ has offered once, and for ever.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But this, for that he continueth for ever, hath an everlasting priesthood:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Whereby he is able also to save for ever them that come to God by him; always living to make intercession for us. Make intercession.... Christ, as man, continually maketh intercession for us, by representing his passion to his Father.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For it was fitting that we should have such a high priest, holy, innocent, undefiled, separated from sinners, and made higher than the heavens:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who needeth not daily (as the other priests) to offer sacrifices, first for his own sins, and then for the people’s: for this he did once, in offering himself.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For the law maketh men priests, who have infirmity: but the word of the oath (which was since the law) the Son who is perfected for evermore. Hebrews Chapter 8 More of the excellence of the priesthood of Christ and of the New Testament.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now of the things which we have spoken, this is the sum: We have such an high priest who is set on the right hand of the throne of majesty in the heavens,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: A minister of the holies and of the true tabernacle, which the Lord hath pitched, and not man. The holies.... That is, the sanctuary.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For every high priest is appointed to offer gifts and sacrifices: wherefore it is necessary that he also should have some thing to offer.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: If then he were on earth, he would not be a priest: seeing that there would be others to offer gifts according to the law. If then he were on earth, etc.... That is, if he were not of a higher condition than the Levitical order of earthly priests, and had not another kind of sacrifice to offer, he should be excluded by them from the priesthood, and its functions, which by the law were appropriated to their tribe.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who serve unto the example and shadow of heavenly things. As it was answered to Moses, when he was to finish the tabernacle: See (saith he) that thou make all things according to the pattern which was shewn thee on the mount. Who serve unto, etc.... The priesthood of the law and its functions were a kind of an example and shadow of what is done by Christ in his church militant and triumphant, of which the tabernacle was a pattern.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But now he hath obtained a better ministry, by how much also he is a mediator of a better testament which is established on better promises.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For if that former had been faultless, there should not indeed a place have been sought for a second.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For, finding fault with them, he saith: Behold the days shall come, saith the Lord: and I will perfect, unto the house of Israel and unto the house of Juda, a new testament:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Not according to the testament which I made to their fathers, on the day when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt: because they continued not in my testament: and I regarded them not, saith the Lord.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For this is the testament which I will make to the house of Israel after those days, saith the Lord: I will give my laws into their mind: and in their heart will I write them. And I will be their God: and they shall be my people.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And they shall not teach every man his neighbour and every man his brother, saying: Know the Lord. For all shall know me, from the least to the greatest of them. They shall not teach, etc.... So great shall be light and grace of the new testament, that it shall not be necessary to inculcate to the faithful the belief and knowledge of the true God, for they shall all know him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Because I will be merciful to their iniquities: and their sins I will remember no more.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now in saying a new, he hath made the former old. And that which decayeth and groweth old is near its end. A new.... Supply ‘covenant’. Hebrews Chapter 9 The sacrifices of the law were far inferior to that of Christ.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: The former indeed had also justifications of divine service and a worldly sanctuary.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For there was a tabernacle made the first, wherein were the candlesticks and the table and the setting forth of loaves, which is called the Holy.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And after the second veil, the tabernacle which is called the Holy of Holies:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Having a golden censer and the ark of the testament covered about on every part with gold, in which was a golden pot that had manna and the rod of Aaron that had blossomed and the tables of the testament.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And over it were the cherubims of glory overshadowing the propitiatory: of which it is not needful to speak now particularly.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now these things being thus ordered, into the first tabernacle, the priests indeed always entered, accomplishing the offices of sacrifices.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But into the second, the high priest alone, once a year: not without blood, which he offereth for his own and the people’s ignorance:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: The Holy Ghost signifying this: That the way into the Holies was not yet made manifest, whilst the former tabernacle was yet standing.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Which is a parable of the time present: according to which gifts and sacrifices are offered, which cannot, as to the conscience, make him perfect that serveth, only in meats and in drinks,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And divers washings and justices of the flesh laid on them until the time of correction. Of correction.... Viz., when Christ should correct and settle all things.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But Christ, being come an high priest of the good things to come, by a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hand, that is, not of this creation:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Neither by the blood of goats or of calves, but by his own blood, entered once into the Holies, having obtained eternal redemption. Eternal redemption.... By that one sacrifice of his blood, once offered on the cross, Christ our Lord paid and exhibited, once for all, the general price and ransom of all mankind: which no other priest could do.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For if the blood of goats and of oxen, and the ashes of an heifer, being sprinkled, sanctify such as are defiled, to the cleansing of the flesh:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: How much more shall the blood of Christ, who by the Holy Ghost offered himself unspotted unto God, cleanse our conscience from dead works, to serve the living God?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And therefore he is the mediator of the new testament: that by means of his death for the redemption of those transgressions which were under the former testament, they that are called may receive the promise of eternal inheritance.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For where there is a testament the death of the testator must of necessity come in.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For a testament is of force after men are dead: otherwise it is as yet of no strength, whilst the testator liveth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Whereupon neither was the first indeed dedicated without blood.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For when every commandment of the law had been read by Moses to all the people, he took the blood of calves and goats, with water, and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book itself and all the people.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Saying: This is the blood of the testament which God hath enjoined unto you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: The tabernacle also and all the vessels of the ministry, in like manner, he sprinkled with blood.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And almost all things, according to the law, are cleansed with blood: and without shedding of blood there is no remission.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: It is necessary therefore that the patterns of heavenly things should be cleansed with these: but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For Jesus is not entered into the Holies made with hands, the patterns of the true: but into Heaven itself, that he may appear now in the presence of God for us.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Nor yet that he should offer himself often, as the high priest entereth into the Holies every year with the blood of others: Offer himself often.... Christ shall never more offer himself in sacrifice, in that violent, painful, and bloody manner, nor can there be any occasion for it: since by that one sacrifice upon the cross, he has furnished the full ransom, redemption, and remedy for all the sins of the world. But this hinders not that he may offer himself daily in the sacred mysteries in an unbloody manner, for the daily application of that one sacrifice of redemption to our souls.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For then he ought to have suffered often from the beginning of the world. But now once, at the end of ages, he hath appeared for the destruction of sin by the sacrifice of himself.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And as it is appointed unto men once to die, and after this the judgment:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: So also Christ was offered once to exhaust the sins of many. The second time he shall appear without sin to them that expect him unto salvation. To exhaust.... That is, to empty, or draw out to the very bottom, by a plentiful and perfect redemption. Hebrews Chapter 10 Because of the insufficiency of the sacrifices of the law, Christ our high priest shed his own blood for us, offering up once for all the sacrifice of our redemption. He exhorts them to perseverance.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For the law, having a shadow of the good things to come, not the very image of the things, by the selfsame sacrifices which they offer continually every year, can never make the comers thereunto perfect.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For then they would have ceased to be offered: because the worshippers once cleansed should have no conscience of sin any longer. They would have ceased.... If they had been of themselves perfect to all the intents of redemption and remission, as Christ’s death is there would have been no occasion of so often repeating them: as there is no occasion for Christ’s dying any more for our sins.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But in them there is made a commemoration of sins every year:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For it is impossible that with the blood of oxen and goats sin should be taken away.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore, when he cometh into the world he saith: Sacrifice and oblation thou wouldest not: but a body thou hast fitted to me.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Holocausts for sin did not please thee.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Then said I: Behold I come: in the head of the book it is written of me: that I should do thy will, O God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: In saying before, Sacrifices, and oblations, and holocausts for sin thou wouldest not, neither are they pleasing to thee, which are offered according to the law.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Then said I: Behold, I come to do thy will, O God: He taketh away the first, that he may establish that which followeth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: In the which will, we are sanctified by the oblation of the body of Jesus Christ once.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And every priest indeed standeth daily ministering and often offering the same sacrifices which can never take away sins.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But this man, offering one sacrifice for sins, for ever sitteth on the right hand of God,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: From henceforth expecting until his enemies be made his footstool.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For by one oblation he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And the Holy Ghost also doth testify this to us. For after that he said:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And this is the testament which I will make unto them after those days, saith the Lord. I will give my laws in their hearts and on their minds will I write them:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And their sins and iniquities I will remember no more.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now, where there is a remission of these, there is no more an oblation for sin. There is no more an oblation for sin.... Where there is a full remission of sins, as in baptism, there is no more occasion for a sin offering to be made for such sins already remitted; and as for sins committed afterwards, they can only be remitted in virtue of the one oblation of Christ’s death.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Having therefore, brethren, a confidence in the entering into the holies by the blood of Christ:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: A new and living way which he hath dedicated for us through the veil, that is to say, his flesh:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And a high priest over the house of God:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Let us draw near with a true heart, in fulness of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with clean water.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Let us hold fast the confession of our hope without wavering (for he is faithful that hath promised):

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And let us consider one another, to provoke unto charity and to good works:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Not forsaking our assembly, as some are accustomed: but comforting one another, and so much the more as you see the day approaching.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For if we sin wilfully after having the knowledge of the truth, there is now left no sacrifice for sins: If we sin wilfully.... He speaks of the sin of wilful apostasy from the known truth; after which, as we can not be baptized again, we can not expect to have that abundant remission of sins, which Christ purchased by his death, applied to our souls in that ample manner as it is in baptism: but we have rather all manner of reason to look for a dreadful judgment; the more because apostates from the known truth, seldom or never have the grace to return to it.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But a certain dreadful expectation of judgment, and the rage of a fire which shall consume the adversaries.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: A man making void the law of Moses dieth without any mercy under two or three witnesses:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: How much more, do you think he deserveth worse punishments, who hath trodden under foot the Son of God and hath esteemed the blood of the testament unclean, by which he was sanctified, and hath offered an affront to the Spirit of grace?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For we know him that hath said: Vengeance belongeth to me, and I will repay. And again: The Lord shall judge his people.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But call to mind the former days, wherein, being illuminated, you endured a great fight of afflictions.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And on the one hand indeed, by reproaches and tribulations, were made a gazingstock; and on the other, became companions of them that were used in such sort.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For you both had compassion on them that were in bands and took with joy the being stripped of your own goods, knowing that you have a better and a lasting substance.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Do not therefore lose your confidence which hath a great reward.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For patience is necessary for you: that, doing the will of God, you may receive the promise.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For yet a little and a very little while, and he that is to come will come and will not delay.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But my just man liveth by faith: but if he withdraw himself, he shall not please my soul.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But we are not the children of withdrawing unto perdition, but of faith to the saving of the soul. Hebrews Chapter 11 What faith is. Its wonderful fruits and efficacy demonstrated in the fathers.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now, faith is the substance of things to be hoped for, the evidence of things that appear not.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For by this the ancients obtained a testimony.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith we understand that the world was framed by the word of God: that from invisible things visible things might be made.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Abel offered to God a sacrifice exceeding that of Cain, by which he obtained a testimony that he was just, God giving testimony to his gifts. And by it he being dead yet speaketh.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Henoch was translated that he should not see death: and he was not found because God had translated him. For before his translation he had testimony that he pleased God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But without faith it is impossible to please God. For he that cometh to God must believe that he is: and is a rewarder to them that seek him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Noe, having received an answer concerning those things which as yet were not seen, moved with fear, framed the ark for the saving of his house: by the which he condemned the world and was instituted heir of the justice which is by faith.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith he that is called Abraham obeyed to go out into a place which he was to receive for an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing whither he went. He that is called Abraham ... or, Abraham being called.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith he abode in the land of promise, as in a strange country, dwelling in cottages, with Isaac and Jacob, the co-heirs of the same promise.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For he looked for a city that hath foundations: whose builder and maker is God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith also Sara herself, being barren, received strength to conceive seed, even past the time of age: because she believed that he was faithful who had promised,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For which cause there sprung even from one (and him as good as dead) as the stars of heaven in multitude and as the sand which is by the sea shore innumerable.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: All these died according to faith, not having received the promises but beholding them afar off and saluting them and confessing that they are pilgrims and strangers on the earth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For they that say these things do signify that they seek a country.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And truly, if they had been mindful of that from whence they came out, they had doubtless, time to return.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But now they desire a better, that is to say, a heavenly country. Therefore, God is not ashamed to be called their God: for he hath prepared for them a city.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Abraham, when he was tried, offered Isaac: and he that had received the promises offered up his only begotten son,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: (To whom it was said: In Isaac shall thy seed be called:)

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Accounting that God is able to raise up even from the dead. Whereupon also he received him for a parable. For a parable.... That is, as a figure of Christ, slain and coming to life again.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith also of things to come Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Jacob, dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph and adored the top of his rod. Adored the top of his rod.... The apostle here follows the ancient Greek Bible of the seventy interpreters, (which translates in this manner, Gen. 47. 31.,) and alleges this fact of Jacob, in paying a relative honour and veneration to the top of the rod or sceptre of Joseph, as to a figure of Christ’s sceptre and kingdom, as an instance and argument of his faith. But some translators, who are no friends to this relative honour, have corrupted the text, by translating it, he worshipped, leaning upon the top of his staff; as if this circumstance of leaning upon his staff were any argument of Jacob’s faith, or worthy the being thus particularly taken notice of by the Holy Ghost.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Joseph, when he was dying, made mention of the going out of the children of Israel and gave commandment concerning his bones.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Moses, when he was born, was hid three months by his parents: because they saw he was a comely babe, and they feared not the king’s edict.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Moses, when he was grown up, denied himself to be the son of Pharao’s daughter:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Rather choosing to be afflicted with the people of God than to have the pleasure of sin for a time:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasure of the Egyptians. For he looked unto the reward.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the fierceness of the king: for he endured, as seeing him that is invisible.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith he celebrated the pasch and the shedding of the blood: that he who destroyed the firstborn might not touch them.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith they passed through the Red Sea, as by dry land: which the Egyptians attempting, were swallowed up.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down, by the going round them seven days.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By faith Rahab the harlot perished not with the unbelievers, receiving the spies with peace.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And what shall I yet say? For the time would fail me to tell of Gedeon, Barac, Samson, Jephthe, David, Samuel, and the prophets:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who by faith conquered kingdoms, wrought justice, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, recovered strength from weakness, became valiant in battle, put to flight the armies of foreigners.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Women received their dead raised to life again. But others were racked, not accepting deliverance, that they might find a better resurrection.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And others had trial of mockeries and stripes: moreover also of bands and prisons.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: They were stoned, they were cut asunder, they were tempted, they were put to death by the sword, they wandered about in sheepskins, in goatskins, being in want, distressed, afflicted:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Of whom the world was not worthy: wandering in deserts, in mountains and in dens and in caves of the earth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And all these, being approved by the testimony of faith, received not the promise:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: God providing some better thing for us, that they should not be perfected without us. Hebrews Chapter 12 Exhortation to constancy under their crosses. The danger of abusing the graces of the New Testament.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And therefore we also having so great a cloud of witnesses over our head, laying aside every weight and sin which surrounds us, let us run by patience to the fight proposed to us:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Looking on Jesus, the author and finisher of faith, who, having joy set before him, endured the cross, despising the shame, and now sitteth on the right hand of the throne of God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For think diligently upon him that endured such opposition from sinners against himself that you be not wearied, fainting in your minds.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For you have not yet resisted unto blood, striving against sin.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And you have forgotten the consolation which speaketh to you, as unto children, saying: My son, neglect not the discipline of the Lord: neither be thou wearied whilst thou art rebuked by him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For whom the Lord loveth he chastiseth: and he scourgeth every son whom he receiveth.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Persevere under discipline. God dealeth with you as with his sons. For what son is there whom the father doth not correct?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But if you be without chastisement, whereof all are made partakers, then are you bastards and not sons.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Moreover, we have had fathers of our flesh for instructors, and we reverenced them. Shall we not much more obey the Father of spirits and live?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And they indeed for a few days, according to their own pleasure, instructed us: but he, for our profit, that we might receive his sanctification.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Now all chastisement for the present indeed seemeth not to bring with it joy, but sorrow: but afterwards it will yield to them that are exercised by it the most peaceable fruit of justice.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore, lift up the hands which hang down and the feeble knees:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And make straight steps with your feet: that no one, halting, may go out of the way; but rather be healed.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Follow peace with all men and holiness: without which no man shall see God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Looking diligently, lest any man be wanting to the grace of God: lest any root of bitterness springing up do hinder and by it many be defiled:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Lest there be any fornicator or profane person, as Esau who for one mess sold his first birthright.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For know ye that afterwards, when he desired to inherit the benediction, he was rejected. For he found no place of repentance, although with tears he had sought it. He found, etc.... That is, he found no way to bring his father to repent, or change his mind, with relation to his having given the blessing to his younger brother Jacob.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For you are not come to a mountain that might be touched and a burning fire and a whirlwind and darkness and storm,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And the sound of a trumpet and the voice of words, which they that heard excused themselves, that the word might not be spoken to them.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For they did not endure that which was said: and if so much as a beast shall touch the mount, it shall be stoned.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And so terrible was that which was seen, Moses said: I am frighted, and tremble.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But you are come to mount Sion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to the company of many thousands of angels,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And to the church of the firstborn who are written in the heavens, and to God the judge of all, and to the spirits of the just made perfect,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And to Jesus the mediator of the new testament, and to the sprinkling of blood which speaketh better than that of Abel.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: See that you refuse him not that speaketh. For if they escaped not who refused him that spoke upon earth, much more shall not we that turn away from him that speaketh to us from heaven.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Whose voice then moved the earth; but now he promiseth, saying: Yet once more: and I will move, not only the earth, but heaven also.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And in that he saith: Yet once more, he signifieth the translation of the moveable things as made, that those things may remain which are immoveable.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Therefore, receiving an immoveable kingdom, we have grace: whereby let us serve, pleasing God, with fear and reverence.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For our God is a consuming fire. Hebrews Chapter 13 Divers admonitions and exhortations.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Let the charity of the brotherhood abide in you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And hospitality do not forget: for by this some, being not aware of it, have entertained angels.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Remember them that are in bands, as if you were bound with them: and them that labour, as being yourselves also in the body.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Marriage honourable in all, and the bed undefiled. For fornicators and adulterers God will judge. Or, Let marriage be honourable in all.... That is, in all things belonging to the marriage state. This is a warning to married people, not to abuse the sanctity of their state, by any liberties or irregularities contrary thereunto. Now it does not follow from this text that all persons are obliged to marry, even if the word omnibus were rendered, in all persons, instead of in all things: for if it was a precept, St. Paul himself would have transgressed it, as he never married. Moreover, those who have already made a vow to God to lead a single life, should they attempt to marry, they would incur their own damnation. 1 Tim. 5. 12.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Let your manners be without covetousness, contented with such things as you have. For he hath said: I will not leave thee: neither will I forsake thee.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: So that we may confidently say: The Lord is my helper: I will not fear what man shall do to me.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Remember your prelates who have spoken the word of God to you: whose faith follow, considering the end of their conversation,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Jesus Christ, yesterday, and today: and the same for ever.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Be not led away with various and strange doctrines. For it is best that the heart be established with grace, not with meats: which have not profited those that walk in them.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: We have an altar whereof they have no power to eat who serve the tabernacle.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For the bodies of those beasts whose blood is brought into the holies by the high priest for sin are burned without the camp.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore Jesus also, that he might sanctify the people by his own blood, suffered without the gate.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Let us go forth therefore to him without the camp, bearing his reproach. Let us go forth therefore to him without the camp, bearing his reproach.... That is, bearing his cross. It is an exhortation to them to be willing to suffer with Christ, reproaches, persecutions, and even death, if they desire to partake of the benefit of his suffering for man’s redemption.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For, we have not here a lasting city: but we seek one that is to come.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: By him therefore let us offer the sacrifice of praise always to God, that is to say, the fruit of lips confessing to his name.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And do not forget to do good and to impart: for by such sacrifices God’s favour is obtained.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Obey your prelates and be subject to them. For they watch as being to render an account of your souls: that they may do this with joy and not with grief. For this is not expedient for you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Pray for us. For we trust we have a good conscience, being willing to behave ourselves well in all things.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And I beseech you the more to do this, that I may be restored to you the sooner.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And may the God of peace, who brought again from the dead the great pastor of the sheep, our Lord Jesus Christ, in the blood of the everlasting testament,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Fit you in all goodness, that you may do his will; doing in you that which is well pleasing in his sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom is glory for ever and ever. Amen.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And I beseech you, brethren, that you suffer this word of consolation. For I have written to you in a few words.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Know ye that our brother Timothy is set at liberty: with whom (if he come shortly) I will see you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Salute all your prelates and all the saints. The brethren from Italy salute you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Grace be with you all. Amen.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: James, the servant of God and of our Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad, greeting.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: My brethren, count it all joy, when you shall fall into divers temptations: Into divers temptations.... The word temptation, in this epistle, is sometimes taken for trials by afflictions or persecutions, as in this place: at other times, it is to be understood, tempting, enticing, or drawing others into sin.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Knowing that the trying of your faith worketh patience

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And patience hath a perfect work: that you may be perfect and entire, failing in nothing.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But if any of you want wisdom, let him ask of God who giveth to all men abundantly and upbraideth not. And it shall be given him.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea, which is moved and carried about by the wind.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Therefore let not that man think that he shall receive any thing of the Lord.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: A double minded man is inconstant in all his ways.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But let the brother of low condition glory in his exaltation:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the rich, in his being low: because as the flower of the grass shall he pass away.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For the sun rose with a burning heat and parched the grass: and the flower thereof fell off, and the beauty of the shape thereof perished. So also shall the rich man fade away in his ways.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for, when he hath been proved, he shall receive the crown of life which God hath promised to them that love him.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Let no man, when he is tempted, say that he is tempted by God. For God is not a tempter of evils: and he tempteth no man.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But every man is tempted by his own concupiscence, being drawn away and allured.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Then, when concupiscence hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin. But sin, when it is completed, begetteth death.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Do not err, therefore, my dearest brethren.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Every best gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no change nor shadow of alteration.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For of his own will hath he begotten us by the word of truth, that we might be some beginning of his creature. Some beginning.... That is, a kind of first fruits of his creatures.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You know, my dearest brethren. And let every man be swift to hear, but slow to speak and slow to anger.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For the anger of man worketh not the justice of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Wherefore, casting away all uncleanness and abundance of naughtiness, with meekness receive the ingrafted word, which is able to save your souls.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But be ye doers of the word and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For if a man be a hearer of the word and not a doer, he shall be compared to a man beholding his own countenance in a glass.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For he beheld himself and went his way and presently forgot what manner of man he was.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But he that hath looked into the perfect law of liberty and hath continued therein, not becoming a forgetful hearer but a doer of the work: this man shall be blessed in his deed.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And if any man think himself to be religious, not bridling his tongue but deceiving his own heart, this man’s religion is vain.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Religion clean and undefiled before God and the Father is this: to visit the fatherless and widows in their tribulation and to keep one’s self unspotted from this world. James Chapter 2 Against respect of persons. The danger of transgressing one point of the law. Faith is dead without works.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: My brethren, have not the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ of glory, with respect of persons. With respect of persons.... The meaning is, that in matters relating to faith, the administering of the sacraments, and other spiritual functions in God’s church, there should be no respect of persons; but that the souls of the poor should be as much regarded as those of the rich. See Deut. 1.17.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For if there shall come into your assembly a man having a golden ring, in fine apparel; and there shall come in also a poor man in mean attire:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And you have respect to him that is clothed with the fine apparel and shall say to him: Sit thou here well: but say to the poor man: Stand thou there, or: Sit under my footstool:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Do you not judge within yourselves, and are become judges of unjust thoughts?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Hearken, my dearest brethren: Hath not God chosen the poor in this world, rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom which God hath promised to them that love him?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But you have dishonoured the poor man. Do not the rich oppress you by might? And do not they draw you before the judgment seats?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Do not they blaspheme the good name that is invoked upon you?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: If then you fulfil the royal law, according to the scriptures: Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself; you do well.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But if you have respect to persons, you commit sin, being reproved by the law as transgressors.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And whosoever shall keep the whole law, but offend in one point, is become guilty of all. Guilty of all; ... That is, he becomes a transgressor of the law in such a manner, that the observing of all other points will not avail him to salvation; for he despises the lawgiver, and breaks through the great and general commandment of charity, even by one mortal sin. For all the precepts of the law are to be considered as one total and entire law, and as it were a chain of precepts, where, by breaking one link of this chain, the whole chain is broken, or the integrity of the law consisting of a collection of precepts. A sinner, therefore, by a grievous offence against any one precept, incurs eternal punishment; yet the punishment in hell shall be greater for those who have been greater sinners, as a greater reward shall be for those in heaven who have lived with greater sanctity and perfection.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For he that said: Thou shalt not commit adultery, said also: Thou shalt not kill. Now if thou do not commit adultery, but shalt kill, thou art become a transgressor of the law.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: So speak ye and so do, as being to be judged by the law of liberty.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For judgment without mercy to him that hath not done mercy. And mercy exalteth itself above judgment.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: What shall it profit, my brethren, if a man say he hath faith, but hath not works? Shall faith be able to save him?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And if a brother or sister be naked and want daily food:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And one of you say to them: Go in peace, be ye warmed and filled; yet give them not those things that are necessary for the body, what shall it profit?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: So faith also, if it have not works, is dead in itself.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But some man will say: Thou hast faith, and I have works. Shew me thy faith without works; and I will shew thee, by works, my faith.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Thou believest that there is one God. Thou dost well: the devils also believe and tremble.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But wilt thou know, O vain man, that faith without works is dead?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Was not Abraham our father justified by works, offering up Isaac his son upon the altar?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Seest thou that faith did cooperate with his works and by works faith was made perfect?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the scripture was fulfilled, saying: Abraham believed God, and it was reputed to him to justice, and he was called the friend of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Do you see that by works a man is justified, and not by faith only?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And in like manner also Rahab the harlot, was not she justified by works, receiving the messengers and sending them out another way?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For even as the body without the spirit is dead: so also faith without works is dead. James Chapter 3 Of the evils of the tongue. Of the difference between the earthly and heavenly wisdom.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be ye not many masters, my brethren, knowing that you receive the greater judgment.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For in many things we all offend. If any man offend not in word, the same is a perfect man. He is able also with a bridle to lead about the whole body.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For if we put bits into the mouths of horses, that they may obey us: and we turn about their whole body.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold also ships, whereas they are great and are driven by strong winds, yet are they turned about with a small helm, whithersoever the force of the governor willeth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Even so the tongue is indeed a little member and boasteth great things. Behold how small a fire kindleth a great wood.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity. The tongue is placed among our members, which defileth the whole body and inflameth the wheel of our nativity, being set on fire by hell.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For every nature of beasts and of birds and of serpents and of the rest is tamed and hath been tamed, by the nature of man.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But the tongue no man can tame, an unquiet evil, full of deadly poison.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: By it we bless God and the Father: and by it we curse men who are made after the likeness of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Out of the same mouth proceedeth blessing and cursing. My brethren, these things ought not so to be.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Doth a fountain send forth, out of the same hole, sweet and bitter water?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear grapes? Or the vine, figs? So neither can the salt water yield sweet.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Who is a wise man and endued with knowledge, among you? Let him shew, by a good conversation, his work in the meekness of wisdom.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But if you have bitter zeal, and there be contentions in your hearts: glory not and be not liars against the truth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For this is not wisdom, descending from above: but earthly, sensual, devilish.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For where envying and contention is: there is inconstancy and every evil work.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But the wisdom that is from above, first indeed is chaste, then peaceable, modest, easy to be persuaded, consenting to the good, full of mercy and good fruits, without judging, without dissimulation.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the fruit of justice is sown in peace, to them that make peace. James Chapter 4 The evils that flow from yielding to concupiscence and being friends to this world. Admonitions against pride, detraction and the like.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: From whence are wars and contentions among you? Are they not hence, from your concupiscences, which war in your members?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You covet, and have not: you kill and envy and cannot obtain. You contend and war, and you have not: because you ask not.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You ask and receive not: because you ask amiss, that you may consume it on your concupiscences.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Adulterers, know you not that the friendship of this world is the enemy of God? Whosoever therefore will be a friend of this world becometh an enemy of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Or do you think that the scripture saith in vain: To envy doth the spirit covet which dwelleth in you?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But he giveth greater grace. Wherefore he saith: God resisteth the proud and giveth grace to the humble.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be subject therefore to God. But resist the devil: and he will fly from you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Draw nigh to God: and he will draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye sinners, and purify your hearts, ye double minded.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be afflicted and mourn and weep: let your laughter be turned into mourning and your joy into sorrow.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be humbled in the sight of the Lord: and he will exalt you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Detract not one another, my brethren. He that detracteth his brother, or he that judgeth his brother, detracteth the law and judgeth the law. But if thou judge the law, thou art not a doer of the law, but a judge.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: There is one lawgiver and judge, that is able to destroy and to deliver.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But who art thou that judgest thy neighbour? Behold, now you that say: To-day or to-morrow we will go into such a city, and there we will spend a year and will traffic and make our gain.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Whereas you know not what shall be on the morrow.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For what is your life? It is a vapour which appeareth for a little while and afterwards shall vanish away. For that you should say: If the Lord will, and, If we shall live, we will do this or that.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But now you rejoice in your arrogancies. All such rejoicing is wicked.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: To him therefore who knoweth to do good and doth it not, to him it is sin. James Chapter 5 A woe to the rich that oppress the poor. Exhortations to patience and to avoid swearing. Of the anointing the sick, confession of sins and fervour in prayer.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Go to now, ye rich men: weep and howl in your miseries, which shall come upon you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Your riches are corrupted: and your garments are motheaten.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Your gold and silver is cankered: and the rust of them shall be for a testimony against you and shall eat your flesh like fire. You have stored up to yourselves wrath against the last days.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold the hire of the labourers who have reaped down your fields, which by fraud has been kept back by you, crieth: and the cry of them hath entered into the ears of the Lord of Sabaoth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You have feasted upon earth: and in riotousness you have nourished your hearts, in the day of slaughter.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You have condemned and put to death the Just One: and he resisted you not.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be patient therefore, brethren, until the coming of the Lord. Behold, the husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the earth: patiently bearing till he receive the early and latter rain.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be you therefore also patient and strengthen your hearts: for the coming of the Lord is at hand.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Grudge not, brethren, one against another, that you may not be judged. Behold the judge standeth before the door.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Take, my brethren, for an example of suffering evil, of labour and patience, the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold, we account them blessed who have endured. You have heard of the patience of Job and you have seen the end of the Lord, that the Lord is merciful and compassionate.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But above all things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, nor by the earth, nor by any other oath. But let your speech be: Yea, Yea: No, No: that you fall not under judgment.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Is any of you sad? Let him pray: Is he cheerful in mind? Let him sing.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Is any man sick among you? Let him bring in the priests of the church and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord. Let him bring in, etc.... See here a plain warrant of scripture for the sacrament of extreme unction, that any controversy against its institution would be against the express words of the sacred text in the plainest terms.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the prayer of faith shall save the sick man. And the Lord shall raise him up: and if he be in sins, they shall be forgiven him.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Confess therefore your sins one to another: and pray one for another, that you may be saved. For the continual prayer of a just man availeth much. Confess your sins one to another.... That is, to the priests of the church, whom (ver.14) he had ordered to be called for, and brought in to the sick; moreover, to confess to persons who had no power to forgive sins, would be useless. Hence the precept here means, that we must confess to men whom God hath appointed, and who, by their ordination and jurisdiction, have received the power of remitting sins in his name.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Elias was a man passible like unto us: and with prayer he prayed that it might not rain upon the earth. And it rained not for three years and six months.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And he prayed again. And the heaven gave rain: and the earth brought forth her fruit.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: My brethren, if any of you err from the truth and one convert him:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: He must know that he who causeth a sinner to be converted from the error of his way shall save his soul from death and shall cover a multitude of sins.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: The Revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave unto him, to make known to his servants the things which must shortly come to pass: and signified, sending by his angel to his servant John, The things which must shortly come; ... and again it is said, ver. 3, The time is at hand.... This can not be meant of all the things prophesied in the Apocalypse, where mention is made also of the day of judgment, and of the glory of heaven at the end of the world. That some things were to come to pass shortly, is evident, by what is said to the Seven Churches, chap. 2 and 3, Or that the persecutions foretold should begin shortly. Or that these words signified, that all time is short, and that from the coming of Christ, we are now in the last age or last hour. See 1 John 2.18.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Who hath given testimony to the word of God and the testimony of Jesus Christ, what things soever he hath seen.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Blessed is he that readeth and heareth the words of this prophecy: and keepeth those things which are written in it. For the time is at hand.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: John to the seven churches which are in Asia. Grace be unto you and peace, from him that is and that was and that is to come: and from the seven spirits which are before his throne:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witness, the first begotten of the dead and the prince of the kings of the earth, who hath loved us and washed us from our sins in his own blood,

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And hath made us a kingdom, and priests to God and his Father. To him be glory and empire for ever and ever. Amen.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold, he cometh with the clouds, and every eye shall see him: and they also that pierced him. And all the tribes of the earth shall bewail themselves because of him. Even so. Amen.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, saith the Lord God, who is and who was and who is to come, the Almighty. I am Alpha and Omega.... These are the names of the first and last letters of the Greek alphabet, and signify the same as what follows: The beginning and the end: the first cause and last end of all beings: who is, and who was, and who is to come, the Almighty.... These words signify the true God only, and are here applied to our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, who is to come again to judge the living and the dead.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I, John, your brother and your partner in tribulation and in the kingdom and patience in Christ Jesus, was in the island which is called Patmos, for the word of God and for the testimony of Jesus.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I was in the spirit on the Lord’s day and heard behind me a great voice, as of a trumpet,

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Saying: What thou seest, write in a book and send to the seven churches which are in Asia: to Ephesus and to Smyrna and to Pergamus and to Thyatira and to Sardis and to Philadelphia and to Laodicea.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And I turned to see the voice that spoke with me. And being turned, I saw seven golden candlesticks:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks, one like to the Son of man, clothed with a garment down to the feet, and girt about the paps with a golden girdle.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And his head and his hairs were white as white wool and as snow. And his eyes were as a flame of fire:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And his feet like unto fine brass, as in a burning furnace. And his voice as the sound of many waters.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And he had in his right hand seven stars. And from his mouth came out a sharp two-edged sword. And his face was as the sun shineth in his power.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And when I had seen him, I fell at his feet as dead. And he laid his right hand upon me, saying: Fear not. I am the First and the Last,

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And alive, and was dead. And behold I am living for ever and ever and have the keys of death and of hell.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Write therefore the things which thou hast seen: and which are: and which must be done hereafter.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: The mystery of the seven stars, which thou sawest in my right hand and the seven golden candlesticks. The seven stars are the angels of the seven churches. And the seven candlesticks are the seven churches. Apocalypse Chapter 2 Directions what to write to the angels or bishops of Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamus and Thyatira.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Unto the angel of the church of Ephesus write: These things saith he who holdeth the seven stars in his right hand, who walketh in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know thy works and thy labour and thy patience and how thou canst not bear them that are evil. And thou hast tried them who say they are apostles and are not: and hast found them liars:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And thou hast patience and hast endured for my name and hast not fainted.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But I have somewhat against thee, because thou hast left thy first charity.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Be mindful therefore from whence thou art fallen: and do penance and do the first works. Or else I come to thee and will move thy candlestick out of its place, except thou do penance.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But this thou hast, that thou hatest the deeds of the Nicolaites, which I also hate.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches: To him that overcometh I will give to eat of the tree of life which is in the paradise of my God.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Smyrna write: These things saith the First and the Last, who was dead and is alive:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know thy tribulation and thy poverty: but thou art rich. And thou art blasphemed by them that say they are Jews and are not, but are the synagogue of Satan.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Fear none of those things which thou shalt suffer. Behold, the devil will cast some of you into prison, that you may be tried: and you shall have tribulation ten days. Be thou faithful unto death: and I will give thee the crown of life.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches: He that shall overcome shall not be hurt by the second death.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Pergamus write: These things saith he that hath the sharp two-edged sword:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know where thou dwellest, where the seat of Satan is. And thou holdest fast my name and hast not denied my faith. Even in those days when Antipas was my faithful witness, who was slain among you, where Satan dwelleth.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But I have against thee a few things: because thou hast there them that hold the doctrine of Balaam who taught Balac to cast a stumblingblock before the children of Israel, to eat and to commit fornication.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: So hast thou also them that hold the doctrine of the Nicolaites.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: In like manner do penance. If not, I will come to thee quickly and will fight against them with the sword of my mouth.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches: To him that overcometh I will give the hidden manna and will give him a white counter: and in the counter, a new name written, which no man knoweth but he that receiveth it.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Thyatira write: These things saith the Son of God, who hath his eyes like to a flame of fire and his feet like to fine brass.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know thy works and thy faith and thy charity and thy ministry and thy patience and thy last works, which are more than the former.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But I have against thee a few things: because thou sufferest the woman Jezabel, who calleth herself a prophetess, to teach and to seduce my servants, to commit fornication and to eat of things sacrificed to idols.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And I gave her a time that she might do penance: and she will not repent of her fornication.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold, I will cast her into a bed: and they that commit adultery with her shall be in very great tribulation, except they do penance from their deeds,

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And I will kill her children with death: and all the churches shall know that I am he that searcheth the reins and hearts. And I will give to every one of you according to your works. But to you I say,

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the rest who are at Thyatira: Whosoever have not this doctrine and who have not known the depths of Satan, as they say: I will not put upon you any other burthen.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Yet that which you have, hold fast till I come.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And he that shall overcome and keep my works unto the end, I will give him power over the nations. Power over the nations.... This shews, that the saints, who are with Christ our Lord in heaven, receive power from him to preside over nations and provinces, as patrons; and shall come with him at the end of the world to execute his will against those who have not kept his commandments.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And he shall rule them with a rod of iron: and as the vessel of a potter they shall be broken:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: As I also have received of my Father. And I will give him the morning star.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches. Apocalypse Chapter 3 Directions what to write to Sardis, Philadelphia and Laodicea.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Sardis write: These things saith he that hath the seven spirits of God and the seven stars: I know thy works, that thou hast the name of being alive. And thou art dead.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Be watchful and strengthen the things that remain, which are ready to die. For I find not thy works full before my God.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Have in mind therefore in what manner thou hast received and heard: and observe and do penance: If then thou shalt not watch, I will come to thee as a thief: and thou shalt not know at what hour I will come to thee.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But thou hast a few names in Sardis which have not defiled their garments: and they shall walk with me in white, because they are worthy.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that shall overcome shall thus be clothed in white garments: and I will not blot out his name out of the book of life. And I will confess his name before my Father and before his angels.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Philadelphia write: These things saith the Holy One and the true one, he that hath the key of David, he that openeth and no man shutteth, shutteth and no man openeth:

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know thy works. Behold, I have given before thee a door opened, which no man can shut: because thou hast a little strength and hast kept my word and hast not denied my name.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold, I will bring of the synagogue of Satan, who say they are Jews and are not, but do lie. Behold, I will make them to come and adore before thy feet. And they shall know that I have loved thee.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Because thou hast kept the word of my patience, I will also keep thee from the hour of temptation, which shall come upon the whole world to try them that dwell upon the earth.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold, I come quickly: hold fast that which thou hast, that no man take thy crown.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that shall overcome, I will make him a pillar in the temple of my God: and he shall go out no more. And I will write upon him the name of my God and the name of the city of my God, the new Jerusalem, which cometh down out of heaven from my God, and my new name.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And to the angel of the church of Laodicea write: These things saith the Amen, the faithful and true witness, who is the beginning of the creation of God: The Amen, ... that is, the true one, the Truth itself; the Word and Son of God. The beginning ... that is, the principle, the source, and the efficient cause of the whole creation.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I know thy works, that thou art neither cold nor hot. I would thou wert cold or hot.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: But because thou art lukewarm and neither cold nor hot, I will begin to vomit thee out of my mouth.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Because thou sayest: I am rich and made wealthy and have need of nothing: and knowest not that thou art wretched and miserable and poor and blind and naked.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: I counsel thee to buy of me gold, fire tried, that thou mayest be made rich and mayest be clothed in white garments: and that the shame of thy nakedness may not appear. And anoint thy eyes with eyesalve, that thou mayest see.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Such as I love, I rebuke and chastise. Be zealous therefore and do penance.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold, I stand at the gate and knock. If any man shall hear my voice and open to me the door, I will come in to him and will sup with him: and he with me.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: To him that shall overcome, I will give to sit with me in my throne: as I also have overcome and am set down with my Father in his throne.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith to the churches. Apocalypse Chapter 4 The vision of the throne of God, the twenty-four ancients and the four living creatures.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: After these things I looked, and behold a door was opened in heaven, and the first voice which I heard, as it were, of a trumpet speaking with me, said: Come up hither, and I will shew thee the things which must be done hereafter.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
Text: And immediately I was in the spirit. And behold, there was a throne set in heaven, and upon the throne one sitting.

Book: The Apocalypse of St. John the Apostle
